textRegions.text: Can be any kind of output you can pass to a pipe.
Search lines in a file or output based on expression
Either include or exclude matched lines
The name of grep derives from a usage in the Unix text editor ed and related programs. Before grep existed as a separate command, the same effect might have been achieved in an editor:
The name of grep derives from a usage in the Unix text editor ed and related programs. Before grep existed as a separate command, the same effect might have been achieved in an editor:
Don’t pipe to grep if you don’t have to:

$ grep -v apple fruits.txt
orange
banana
pear
lemon
Don’t pipe to grep if you don’t have to:

$ grep -v apple fruits.txt
orange
banana
pear
lemon
Count number of matches in a file:

$ grep -C 1 orange fruits.txt
apple
orange
banana

#! /bin/sed -f
# 
# turing.sed -- emulate a Turing machine
#
# Christophe Blaess <ccb@club-internet.fr>
# http://perso.club-internet.fr/ccb/

# See text file for information about Turing Machine script.

# Read all the instructions, and add a final newline.
:read
N
$!b read
G

# Delete comments extending from a '#' to the end of the line.
s/#[^\n]*\n//g
s/#.*$//g

# Use a colon to separate the instructions.
s/\n/:/g

# Is there an initial tape ?
/|/ s/\(.*\)|\([^:]\)\([^:]*\):\(.*\)/|\2|\3:\1\4/

# else insert a blank one.
/|/!s/\(.*\)/| |:\1/

# Reserve the storage place at the beginning of the pattern space,
# then set the current state to zero.
s/\(.*\)/0x\1/

# Start the machine !
:loop
	# Display only the tape and the state.
	h
	# (comment out the next two lines to see internal data when
	#  debuging TM script)
	s/:.*//
	s/^\(.\)./(\1) /
	p
	g

	# Check the content of the current cell.
	/|[^:|]|/!{
		s/.*/Internal error in the Turing machine/
		q
	}

	# Store in second position the symbol read on the tape
	s/^\(.\).\(.*\)|\(.\)|\(.*\)/\1\3\2|\3|\4/

	# Have we reached a final state ?
	/^\(.\).*:\1/!{
		s/\(.\).*/Final state \1 reached... end of processing/
		q
	}

	# Is there an instruction for this state and this cell content ?
	/^\(..\).*:\1/!{
		s/^\(.\)\(.\).*/No instruction for state \1 and cell \2/
		q
	}
		
	# Look for the new content to write.
	/^\(..\).*:\1[^:|]/!{
		s/.*/I can't write this symbol on the tape!/
		q
	}
	s/^\(..\)\(.*\)|.|\(.*\):\1\(.\)/\1\2|\4|\3:\1\4/
			
	# Look for the direction of movement.
	/^\(..\).*:\1.[ LRlr]/!{
		s/.*/Movement must be specified as L, R or space/
		q
	}
	# Clear the substitute flag that we will use later.
	t nop
	:nop
	/^\(..\).*:\1. / {
		# Direction = ' ' -> Don't move the head
		b end_move
	}
	/^\(..\).*:\1.[Ll]/ {
		# Move the head to the left if the tape is long enough,
		s/^\(..\)\(.*\)\(.\)|\(.\)|/\1\2|\3|\4/
		t end_move
		# else extend the tape with an empty cell.
		s/|\(.\)|/| |\1/
		b end_move
	}

	# Move the head to the right, if the tape is long enough,
	s/|\(.\)|\([^:]\)/\1|\2|/
	t end_move
	# else extend the tape with an empty cell.
	s/|\(.\)|/\1| |/

	:end_move

	# Check the new state,
	/^\(..\).*:\1..[^:|]/!{
		s/.*/I can't use this symbol as new state/
		q
	}
	# then switch the machine state
	s/^\(.\)\(.\)\(.*\):\1\2\(..\)\(.\)/\5\2\3:\1\2\4\5/
	
	# Garbage collector : cut the blank portions of the tape,
	# on the left,
	s/\(..\) */\1/
	# then on the right.
	s/\(..\)\([^:]\) *:/\1\2:/
	
	b loop

###### end of the script
Convert double quotes to single quotes:

$ echo '"Hi" said he.' | sed "s/\"/'/g"
‘Hi’ said he.

$ echo "The cow jumped over the moon." | sed 's/cow/moo-&/'
The moo-cow jumped over the moon.
Use a single back reference to a match:

$ echo "The cow jumped over the moon." | sed 's/\(cow\)/moo-\1/'
The moo-cow jumped over the moon.

$ echo "The cow jumped over the moon." | sed 's/.*\(cow\).*\(moon\).*/\1s like \2s./'
cows like moons.
BEGIN, END, conditionals, comparisons, variables, etc.
An awk program will take on the following general layout.  BEGIN & END blocks are optional:

row1 foo
row2 foo
row3 foo
row4 bar
row5 bar
row6 baz
BEGIN blocks are processed prior to reading any lines
END blocks are processed after all lines have been read
awk 'BEGIN {print "Start parsing..."} {OFS=”: “; print NR,$1} END {print "End parsing."}' demo_file
Start parsing...1: row12: row23: row34: row45: row56: row6End parsing.
awk 'BEGIN {print "Start parsing..."} {OFS=”: “; print NR,$1} END {print "End parsing."}' demo_file
Start parsing...1: row12: row23: row34: row45: row56: row6End parsing.

What’s this?
There are a few special variables built into awk:

1. NR = Number Record
2. NF = Number Field
3. FS = Input Field Separator
4. RS = Record Separator
5. OFS = Output Field Separator
6. ORS = Output Record Separator
Monitor specific file types in Apache logs
Watch Apache logs for requests over 500KB
Sum & Average file sizes in a directory listing
Print most used commands in your history
Get fields in a file for ‘awk’ or ‘cut’ commands
Monitor	Specific File Types in Apache Logs

tail -f /storage/logs/access_log_aweber | \awk '/.(flv|pdf) /  {    printf "%20s\t%20s\t%50s\t%10d b\t%10d ms\t%.3f mbps\n",$7,$3,$10,$13,$NF,(($NF/($13*0.000001))/1024/1024)  }' | \sed 's/^\[//'

05/Apr/2012:04:54:09	      175.141.212.48	                    /videos/thankyou-coi/gmail.flv	    303116 b	   4947171 ms	15.565 mbps05/Apr/2012:04:54:14	       125.165.55.48	                    /videos/thankyou-coi/yahoo.flv	    260501 b	  13747518 ms	50.329 mbps05/Apr/2012:04:54:22	      180.249.224.53	                    /videos/thankyou-coi/yahoo.flv	    260501 b	   5618460 ms	20.569 mbps05/Apr/2012:04:54:34	       99.104.170.38	            /aweber-scholarship-payout-details.pdf	     81019 b	      5874 ms	0.069 mbps
Watch Apache Logs for Requests Over 500KB

tail -f /storage/logs/access_log_aweber | \egrep -v 'thank-you.(swf|flv)|/videos/kb/.*.flv' | \awk '  BEGIN {    printf "%-15s\t%-50s\t%-3s\t%-8s\n","IP","URI","RESPONSE","SIZE(MB)"  }  {    printf "%s\t%-50s\t%-8s\t%0.3f\n",$3,$10,$12,($13/1024/1024)  }' | \awk '$4 > 0.5'
Sum & Average File Sizes in a Directory Listing
ls -l | \awk '  {    sum += $5; n++;  } END {    printf "SUM: %0.2fMB - AVG: %0.2fMB\n",(sum/1024^2), ((sum/1024^2)/n)  }'
Print Most Used Commands in Your Shell History
history | \awk '  {    a[$2]++  } END {    for(i in a) {      print a[i] " " i    }  }' | \sort -nr | \head
2017 git1299 knife835 ssh802 cd639 ls537 clear345 svn230 vim213 vs177 cat
04/01/2012 [svc] Logging 100k action04/02/2012 [svc] Logging 123k action04/03/2012 [svc] Logging 90k action04/04/2012 [svc] Logging 233k action

1: 04/01/2012 [svc] Logging 100k action	1: 04/01/2012	2: [svc]	3: Logging	4: 100k	5: action	4: 90k	5: action

[[ ... snip ... ]]
4: 04/04/2012 [svc] Logging 233k action	1: 04/04/2012	2: [svc]	3: Logging	4: 233k	5: action
head awk_field_demo | \awk '  {    print NR": "$0    for(i=1;i<=NF;++i)      print "\t"i": "$i  }'
A simpler way to cut up a line into fields
‘awk’ can replace ‘cut’, but ‘cut’ can be simpler sometimes
barbarbazfoofoofoo
row4 barrow5 barrow6 bazrow1 foorow2 foorow3 foo
row1 foorow2 foorow3 foorow4 barrow5 barrow6 baz

notes.slide-19: printf is a handy way to do more complex formatting of the output.
notes.slide-15:
NR = Line number currently being parsed
NF = Number of fields in the current line
FS = What each field is separated with (generally provided via the ‘-F’ command-line option)
RS = Define what separates a record (a ‘/n’ by default, but can be redefined)
OFS = What to separate ‘print’-ed items with (ie, ‘print $1,$2’ - separates $1 & $2 with ‘OFS’)
ORS = What to separate each ‘print’-ed output line with (a ‘/n’ by default)
notes.slide-2: A ‘pipe’ is a way of passing the output of one command as input to another command.
notes.slide-22:
a[$2]++ <-- builds an array of unique words and sets each word’s count plus 1 when encountered

Honorable mentions:
 * ‘sort -nr’ -- sort the output by the first column as a number in reverse order (descending)
 * ‘head’ -- only show the top 10 items in the list after sorting
